ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: improved chinese grammar, vocabularly, more knowledge on culture
I learned how to write Chinese primarily. I also learned about different grammatical structures, vocab, cultural ideas, and manners of speech.
Writing skills and being able to articulate ideas more clearly in Chinese.
Developed writing and speaking skills. Learned more about our Chinese identity.
advanced skills in chinese vocabulary, speaking, and understanding.

I never formally learned Chinese before this class; all the Chinese I knew came from conversing with my parents and casually studying Chinese in my free time, so I was apprehensive before coming into this class. However, this class was taught at a great pace, and it patched lots of holes in my Chinese foundations, whether that's grammar, vocabulary, or just general cultural knowledge. I'm really glad I took this class with Wang laoshi this semester!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths - nicely organized, smaller class creates fun environment and good conversation
weaknesses - a lot of work piled up in the end

The course is really strong. Wang laoshi is extremely engaging in class and made attending class very enjoyable. I learned a lot about Chinese culture, and though it was painful in the process I think the writing component of the class is a huge strength - I knew very little handwriting before coming into this class, but now I can handwrite entire paragraphs. However, I'd improve the course through a better textbook, as oftentimes the exercises were incredibly unclear and felt somewhat useless. I'd also implement more speaking opportunities - the speaking homework was ungraded, and sometimes I wish I had feedback to improve my speaking mannerisms and pronunciation.

Strengths: discussions in class were very interesting and level of engagement was high. Definitely take this class if you are on the fence.

Weaknesses: I think the in class tingxie should be taken after a lesson on new material, rather than before the words are taught by the instructor.
The professor was very engaging, and class conversations were always interesting. I wish we developed more reading skills.

strength - overall very well taught class and well organized, format and structure was effective in increasing participation and engagement, material was taught well
weakness - relatively frequent assignments that sometimes seems unnecessary and ineffective

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it's a great way to improve your chinese and be surrounded by people from a similar background and engage in conversation

I would highly recommend this course. It's rather low pressure for a language class, and Wang laoshi is a great teacher who is both understanding and strict. If you're interested in taking your Chinese (Especially reading + writing skills) to the next level, this is the class to go to.
Yes, decently straightforward way to get the language credit out the way.
Yep. Nice, chill way to practice Chinese and get a language credit.

i would definitely recommend this course to other people looking to get lots of practice and see improvement with their chinese skills. this class definitely prepares you well and sets you up for success.
